title: Protocol for generating monoclonal CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockout cell lines using RNPs and lipofection in HNSCC cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Seeding cells for transfection
Timing: 1 day
Seeding the cells on a 24-well plate 24 h prior to transfection to achieve a confluency of 50%–60%.
Check cultured cells for possible contamination.
Detach the cells by trypsinization and quantify the cell numbers by using a hemocytometer or a counting chamber.
Seed 50,000 cells in 500 μL culture medium on a 24-well plate.
Incubate for 24 h at 37°C and 5% CO2.
Note: The distinct cell number may differ in other cell types, depending on the doubling time.
Preparation of gRNA
Timing: 30 min
In this step the crRNA and tracrRNA are annealed to obtain the sgRNA.
Prepare 100 μM solution of Alt-R® CRISPR/Cas9 crRNA (IDT™) and Alt-R® CRISPR/Cas9 tracrRNA (IDT™) in Nuclease Free Duplex Buffer (IDT™).
Preparation of 1 μM gRNA solution in nuclease free water in a sterile tube.
1:1 mixture of 100 μM crRNA and tracrRNA.
Dilute 1:100 in nuclease free water.
Place the tube in preheated thermoblock at 95°C for 5 min.
Cool down to room temperature on benchtop.
Critical: If the annealed sgRNA needs to be stored for repeated use, aliquots should be made to reduce freeze-thaw cycles. Storage at −80°C will prolong the lifetime for up to 18 months.
Lipofection of RNPs in HN cells
Timing: 2 days
Lipofection of RNPs is achieved by using Lipofectamine™ CRISPRMAX™ (Invitrogen™) and RNP assembly with TrueCut™ Cas9 Protein v2 (Invitrogen™).
Prepare cells for transfection.
Check each well for optimal confluency and possible contamination
Remove culture medium and wash cells with 500 μL/well warm PBS
Add 500 μL fresh warmed up culture medium
Note: The cells should be 50%–60% confluent at the time of transfection. Transfection efficiency could be affected by either lower or higher confluency.
Prepare two separate tubes with the following reagents.

Critical: Diluted CRISPERMAX™ Reagent should not sit for > 3 min for optimal transfection efficiency.
Add tube 1 to tube 2 and mix well.
Incubate for 5–10 min at room temperature.
Note: RNP-complexes are forming within this step.
Critical: Do not incubate for > 30 min.
Add 70 μL/well of the prepared solution to the wells.
Incubate for 48 h at 37°C and 5% CO2.
Note: In HN cells editing efficiency was highly dependent on the used RNP concentration. No changes in cell expansion or the number of single cell clones per 96-well plate later on were observed with different RNP concentrations.
Single cell cloning with limiting dilution
Timing: 2–3 weeks
Single cells are seeded in 96-well plates and screened for single cell colonies for about 2–3 weeks.
Note: Depending on the cell type, the required time for cell expansion and single clone screening may differ.
Detach transfected cells by trypsinization and transfer in a 1,5 mL sterile tube.
Count the cells by using a hemocytometer or a counting chamber.
Critical: We highly recommend to first determine the editing efficiency of your different guide sequences at this step, before proceeding with the complete protocol.
Perform PCR, sanger sequencing and analysis as described in step 26 and following. Pick the most efficient guide sequence to perform the knock-out.
Dilute the suspension to 0,5 cells/100 μL in culture medium.
Note: You can use 0.2–0.8 cells/100 μL depending on your cell type.
Add 100 μL/well of your diluted suspension to a 96-well plate.
Critical: Seed 1000 cells in your A1 well for easy adjustment of the microscope later on.
Note: For increased likelihood of knock-out clones, Fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) is suitable surface proteins.
Incubate at 37°C and 5% CO2 for about 4–7 days. Do not move the plate.

When the colonies can easily be identified under the microscope (100×), proceed with selecting the wells with just one colony. Discard the wells with two or more colonies. Change of culture medium can be done every 3–4 days.
Note: Colonies are often forming at the edges of the wells and can easily be overlooked.
Incubate the plate at 37°C and 5% CO2 for about two more weeks or until the confluency of the wells reaches about 50%.
Detach the identified single cell colonies (well by well) by trypsinization and transfer to a 24- well plate containing 500 μL/well culture medium.
Note: If desired, you can transfer the colonies to a 48-well plate at first and to a 24-well plate in the next step. This depends on your cell type.
Incubate at 37°C and 5% CO2 until a confluency of about 50–70% is reached.
Detach the cells by trypsinization (well by well) and count the cells by using a hemocytometer or a counting chamber.
Keep 10,000 cells for further analysis in a sterile 1,5 mL tube (proceed with the next step) and seed the rest on a 6-well plate containing 1 mL/well culture medium. After analysis, keep your desired clones and culture them to your specifications.
PCR and DNA purification
Timing: 5 h
You proceed with the kept 10.000 cells. DNA extraction, PCR and DNA purification is done.
We used Phire Tissue PCR Master Mix (Thermo Fisher) for DNA extraction and PCR. The DNA purification was done with the qiaQuick DNA purification Kit (Qiagen).
Spin down your solution with your kept 10,000 cells at 1300 rpm for 3 min.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 20 μL Dilution Buffer and add 0.5 μL DNARelease Additive.
Mix briefly by vortexing.
Incubate the tube 5 min at room temperature.

Place the tube in a preheated thermoblock at 98°C for 2 min.
Spin down the solution at 1300 rpm for 3 min.
Transfer the supernatant in a new sterile tube.
Pause point: The supernatant can be stored at −20°C if not used immediately.
For each 20 μL PCR reaction, add 10 μL Phire Tissue MasterMix, 1 μL forward primer, 1 μL reverse primer, 7 μL nuclease free water and 1 μL of your sample in a new sterile PCR tube. See the following table:

Critical: The perfect annealing temperature may vary according to your primers.
Note: Optimal annealing temperature for your specific primers can be obtained by checking the Thermo Fisher Tm Calculator, available on the manufacturer’s web page. If needed, a temperature gradient can be used to further optimize the annealing temperature.
For DNA purification mix 20 μL of the PCR product with 100 μL PB-Buffer.
Add 10 μL 3M sodium acetate pH 5.0.
Transfer mixture to a spin-column and spin down at 13,000 rpm for 60 s.
Discard flow-through.
Add 750 μL PE-Buffer to spin-column and centrifuge at 13,000 rpm for 60 s.
Discard flow-through.
Spin down the spin-column for additional 60 s at 13,000 rpm.
Place the spin-column in a new sterile 1,5 mL tube.
For DNA elution add 25 μL nuclease free water to the center of the spin-column.
Let it stand for 60 s.
Spin down at 13,000 rpm for 60 s.
Pause point: The purified DNA solution can be stored at −20°C, if not used immediately.
Analysis of potential knock-out clones
Timing: 2 h

For detailed analysis, our clones were sent for sanger sequencing, done by Eurofins (Ebersberg) Mix2Seq-Kit. With the chromatograms possible knockouts can be identified by using online tools such as ICE (Synthego) or TIDE.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
For further analysis on protein level, methods like Western Blot or FACS are suitable.
Prepare your samples according to the manufacturers guide for sanger sequencing. We used the forward primers as sequencing primers.
Critical: Please note, that one sequence of your wild type is also needed for analysis
Upload your data to given online tools and identify potential knockouts.
Confirm the knockout on protein level.
